Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Climate Controls on Aerosol Fluxes to Taylor Dome and Taylor Glacier
Award.AbstractNarration:
1246702/Aciego

This award supports a collaborative project to analyze ice from the Taylor Dome core and exposed ice from Taylor Glacier to measure variations in the isotopic composition of Strontium, Neodymium, and Hafnium, trace element concentrations, major anions and cations, and dust size data in order to assign provenance of dust within the ice. The intellectual merit of the proposed work is to provide provenance information that will be used to investigate the dust flux response to large, rapid regional and global (hemispheric) climate changes on a millenia scale. The first part of the work will focus on ice from the Taylor Dome core and then transition to surface ice from Taylor Glacier. The PIs will collect large-sized samples of known age based on the methane and oxygen isotope composition of the trapped gases; samples will be large enough to carry out measurements on different size fractions. Parallel work will be done to determine the radiogenic isotope values of southern hemisphere (New Zealand, Australia, South Africa) and local (Northern and Southern Victoria Land) dust source material that are potentially entrained and deposited across the Taylor Dome region. The broader impacts of this research encompass collaborative, outreach, educational, and diversity initiatives. The work will be an international collaboration with researchers at the University of Michigan, Ohio State University, Università Milano-Bicocca, and Università di Pisa, the latter two in Italy. Dissemination of research findings will include both scientific forums and public lectures. Funding will provide support for one PhD student, one MS student, and at least one undergraduate student. The project participants will be involved in the new UC Irvine American Indian Summer School in Earth System Science for high school students using this project as a jumping off point for discussing polar issues and climate change. This award has field work in Antarctica

POR.DRECONTENT:
Trace elements analyzed in the “horizontal ice core” extracted from Taylor Glacier in East Antarctica, provide insights onto the sources and origin of liquid/solid atmospheric particles (the so-called aerosols) transported to and deposited in this area over the last ~40,000 years during the last climatic cycle. Most often, differences in their elemental concentrations can be attributed to variations in pathways and sources of dust originating from the terrestrial crust deflated from continental areas.

            A first group of elements (Al, V, Mn, Rb, Nb, Ba and U) is characterized by no excess with respect to the expected average crustal composition throughout the entire time period covered by the Taylor Glacier ice samples. This illustrates that the source of these elements was primarily mineral dust of continental origin during both the last glacial and the warm Holocene (last 12,000 years) periods. A second group of elements (Li, Na, Cr, Co, and Sr) exhibits no crustal excess throughout the last glacial period, while enrichment is observed during the Holocene. This suggests that their atmospheric cycles are primarily dominated by mineral dust during cold periods, whereas the enrichment during the recent warm period may be the result of environmental changes at the source areas (e.g. shift in moisture saturation of the soil), or transport pathways. A third group of elements (As and Bi) shows even higher enrichments during the Holocene that could indicate a more variable, uncharacterized source, such as emissions from local volcanoes.

            We also found that the average Na/Sr ratio in the Taylor Glacier samples is higher during the last glacial period (~240) than during the Holocene (~185). This could be attributed to a larger input of sea salt originating from icy formations (sea flowers) on newly generated sea ice during the last glacial period, as previous studies have noted their role as salt sources to East Antarctica. Alternatively, the higher sea salt concentrations could be a reflection of gustier conditions from the Southern Ocean, which have also been cited as the cause of increased mineral dust emissions and transport from South America during the last glacial period.

            Another important observation is that the majority of Taylor Glacier samples from the Holocene display an anomaly in the composition of Eu, when compared to the other Rare Earth Elements. This was also observed in the Taylor Dome ice core record that was previously obtained uphill of the Taylor Glacier. This same anomaly is not present in local Ross Sea geological sources, but it is found in young volcanic source area dust from Patagonia in southern South America. The Eu anomaly appears consistently in Holocene samples, in contrast to the current understanding that aeolian dust in East Antarctic ice originated from various source areas during this warm period.

            This project was developed in the framework of an initiative that started a new collaboration between the Byrd Polar and Climate Research Center (BPCRC) at The Ohio State University and the University of Michigan. BPCRC hosted and trained two PhD students from the University of Michigan in the ICP-SFMS analysis and the study of trace elements in ice cores. This program also supported one post-doc student from Mexico.
